--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Pigneri, Rocco" <rpigner=
i@...> wrote:
>
> Bob,
> 
>  
> 
> Given that the tests correctly appear in=
 the JUnit test suite, it seems
> to me that the problem is in the Ant runn=
er and not in JUnit itself.
> Since I am not very familiar with Ant and hav=
e recently switched back to
> JUnit after a few years on NUnit, I am not ce=
rtain if this is something
> that we here can help you with.  An ant list m=
ight be more helpful.
> 
>  
> 
> Other than that, the only thing that I ca=
n think of is to go back to the
> basics and see what you can find out: whi=
ch version of JUnit is Ant
> running?  What command line call is it using? =
 Is there an option not to
> report Ignore'd tests?  Is there a bug in that=
 version of JUnit such
> that Ignore'd tests are not reported?  Will upgrad=
ing JUnit or Ant solve
> the problem?  I'm sure you get the idea J.
> 
> 
>=
 Hope that helps,
> 
>  
> 
> Rocco
> 
>  
>

> >
> > Dea=
r Bob,

> > 
> > You need to use both the @Test and the @Ignore an=
notations in order to
> > get the behavior that you want. Without the @Test=
 annotation, the test
> > runner does not consider the function a test and =
ignores it.
> > 
> Rocco,
> Thanks for the hint. I tried it, but it didn't =
seem to change the ant
> output:
> 
> $ ant unittest
> [snip]
> unittest:
>=
 [junit] Running TTest
> [junit] Tests run: 2, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Time=
 elapsed: 0.103 sec
> 
> [Note: no indication of ignored tests, above, or i=
n the generated HTML
> report.]
>

jar:classes:test-classes
> org.junit.runner.JUnitCore TTest
> JUnit version=
 4.3.1
> .I.
> Time: 0.022
> 
> OK (2 tests)
>

ner indicates "I", which I'm assuming means
> "ignored". Is there any runne=
r/formatter combination that makes this
> information more explicit?

rds,
